text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
Congress makes the following findings:

Nationwide, the number of hate groups in the United States has increased by 67 percent since 2000
			 according to the Southern Poverty Law Center.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:

			 ethnicity or national origin stemmed from anti-Latino bias.

text.#text: According to the

Between 2003 through 2006 and 2007 through 2011 the percentage of hate crimes motivated by
			 religious bias more than doubled from 10 percent to 21 percent.

Violent hate crime increased more than 30 percent as a proportion of all nonfatal violent crime,
			 from 3 percent in 2003 through 2006 to 4 percent in 2007 through 2011.
In New York State—
hate crimes grew 30 percent between 2011 and 2012;

26 percent of all hate crimes reported were due to an individual’s sexual orientation or perceived
			 sexual orientation in 2012;
anti-Black hate crimes made up 25 percent of reported hate crimes against people in 2012; and

22 percent of total hate crimes were anti-Jewish, while almost 65 percent of all property hate
			 crimes were anti-Jewish in 2012.

According to the Bureau of Justice Statistics, an average of more than 250,000 people a year are
			 victims of hate crimes.
